content.text: You have been provided with a metre rule with a string attached to it
● Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 1.1
● Add masses to the mass hanger so that mass \(m\) is \(80\mathrm{g}\)
● Adjust the pivot so that it is \(5\mathrm{mm}\) from end B of the rule. The distance between the string at end A and the pivot is \(L\)
● Measure and record \(L\)
L =
● Adjust the string loop supporting the \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass so that it is approximately \(60\mathrm{cm}\) from end A
● Hold the rule at end A so that the rule is approximately horizontal
Increase \(m\). Measure the new values of \(y_{1}\) and \(y_{2}\)
Repeat until you have five sets of values of \(m\), \(y_{1}\) and \(y_{2}\)
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(y\) in your table
Plot a graph of \(y\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(m\) on the \(x\)-axis
Draw the straight line of best fit
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line
gradient =
y-intercept =
It is suggested that the quantities \(y\) and \(m\) are related by the equation
where \(A\) and \(B\) are constants
Using your answers in **(c)**(iii), determine the values of \(A\) and \(B\)
Give appropriate units
A =
B =

where \(R\) is the mass of the metre rule
Determine a value for \(R\)
Give your answer to three significant figures
In this experiment, you will investigate the equilibrium of a metre rule
· The wooden cylinder labelled A has diameter \(D\)
Measure and record \(D\)
D =
● The wooden cylinder labelled B has diameter \(d\)
Measure and record \(d\)
d =
You have been provided with a wooden strip with a line drawn on one face

· Use the stand, boss and clamp to set up the wooden strip in the position shown in Fig. 2.1. The end near the line should touch the bench and the other end should be approximately \(5\mathrm{cm}\) above the bench
● Place cylinder B approximately \(30\mathrm{cm}\) from the end of the strip
● The distance between the end of the strip and B is \(L\), as shown in Fig. 2.2
Measure and record \(L\)
● Place cylinder A on the line on the strip as shown in Fig. 2.3
● Release A
● A will roll down the strip and along the bench until it collides with B
B will roll and then come to rest as shown in Fig. 2.4
The distance between B and the end of the strip is \(l\), as shown in Fig. 2.4
Measure and record \(l\)
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(l\). Show your working
percentage uncertainty =   .........
Calculate \((l - L)^2\)
Measure and record the diameter \(D\) of cylinder C
D =
● Using cylinder C instead of cylinder A on the wooden strip, repeat **(b)(i)**, **(b)(ii)** and **(b)(iv)**
L =
l =

first value of \(k =\)

Explain whether your results support the suggested relationship
It is suggested that the relationship between \(l, L, D\) and \(d\) is
where \(k\) is a constant
Describe four sources of uncertainty or limitations of the procedure for this experiment
Describe four improvements that could be made to this experiment. You may suggest the use of other apparatus or different procedures
**You may not need to use all of the materials provided.**
In this experiment, you will investigate the result of a collision between two cylinders
